bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, November 22, 1900

div1.p: Reed expresses concern for his wife's gout, but he also teases her. He relates a newspaper controversy over the yellow fever experiments, particularly concerning the American and Spanish volunteers, and consent forms.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, November 22, 1900
div1.opener:
Columbia Barracks,
Novr 22, 1900
Thursday
night-
My precious wifie:
div1.p:
Although it
is nearly 11 o'clock, I can't go
to bed until I have written,
if only a line, to my sweet oom-
sey with the Gout in her darl-
ing foot and “toseys”. Mr Mantee,
in the midst of his work, has
thought of you so many times
today and wondered whether
his sweet wifie was suffer-
ing any pain or not, and whether,
while darling joy had gone
to school, there was anybody
to rub her leg and so take
the pain away. I am so
anxious for Saturday to come
so that I can hear that you
are so much better and able
to get along on yours feet once
more. Dear Me! those cakes of
old Mrs. Greer's were too rich
for your blood entirely! Does-
n't Dr Nash allow you any
of those horrid “cock-tails”, that
you used to try to give me?
I guess that “cocktails” with “cake
and sich” have done the “gouty
business”- or didn't you man-
age to give your foot or leg
a twist of some kind, that you
have forgotten? Tell me all
about it when you next
write.

Friday - Novr 23rd. I couldn't write
any more, last night, but
must jot down a few words
this afternoon- I hope
that my sweet oomsey is
much better, to-day, or entire
ly recovered from her gouty
affliction. The days pass very
rapidly here, but there is
very little that I can do-
my experimental station is
complete except one of the
buildings. I have five amer-
ican non-immunes, three of
whom are ready to try any
kind of experiment I shall
propose, while the other two
will try the infected bed-
ding test- I have, also, 6
spanish immigrants, recently
arrived who are working
as laborer's around the
camp - whether when we
make the offer to them, they
will be willing to accept
and give their written con-
sent, I don't know- Already
some anonymous correspon-
dent has been writing to
one of the Spanish papers in
Havana, telling about what
we propose to do, and this paper,
“La Discussion”, is calling upon
the authorities to stop the “hor-
ror”, as it designates our ex-
periments- We have thought
it best to have the Spanish
consul interviewed, there-
fore, and he very properly
takes a sensible view of the
matter, & sees no reason
why the observations should
not be made on any one
who gives his full written
consent, after the danger
has been explained to him.
So that as far as Spain's rep-
resentative is concerned,
we need give ourselves
no bother. Of course, the
newspapers here are just
like those in the U.S- any-
thing, however false, so that
a sensation is produced
and the paper sold.
The Havana Post, the only
English paper in town, has
made no comments so
far and I have no reason
to think that it will-
However, I shall pay no
attention to any of them
Friday night. I have just returned
from making my party call on Dr
& Mrs. Stark, and found them sitting
in their little quarters and looking
very happy and contented. Mrs.
Stark is a very charming
girl and makes life lots brighter
at this end of the garrison than
it would otherwise be- I
took a glass of sherry and a
bite of cake with them-
Perhaps my sweet wifie
will be afraid that I too will
get the gout, if I don't stop
taking so much punch, cham-
pagne and sherry; but there
is really very little danger
for I indulge very lightly in
these things. I hope that
Dr Nash has made you throw
away those horrid cock-tails,
or had my sweet oomseys drunk
them all before her attack
of misery in the foot!

This afternoon, I went with
Dr Agramonte to the experimen-
tal station and had him talk
with the Spaniards about our
experimental proposition.
To my surprise, they were all
quite willing to undergo
any form of experiment. They
said that they had never had
so much to eat or been treated
so kindly in all their lives, and
that they expected to get yel-
low fever anyway, when they
went to Havana. So that we
will not lack for material
on which to make our obser-
vations- If it were only August
23rd instead of Novr 23rd, we could
soon be able to arrive at some
very interesting results. As it
is, I can't help thinking that the
parasite will develop much more
slowly, during this weather, in the
bodies of the mosquitoes, and that
we must keep the latter alive
at least 18-20 days, if we would
get any results- Time will tell
however, and I feel greatly encour-
aged. Saturday Morning 24th. Good
morning, my sweet wifie, dear! Did you
sleep well last night? And had no
pain? I sincerely hope so. I didn't retire
till after eleven, & hence I am still sleepy,
but I had to jump up and close this
patchwork of a little letter to my precious
oomsey, “wid de Gout”! Boo! Boo! no
toddies, no mother Greer's cakes, but lots of
mineral water! Love & kisses for my dear girls.
